headline: 12 burnt to death in Ilorin-Ogbomoso road crash
summarized_story:
Tragedy struck on Saturday when 12 persons were burnt to death in an auto crash on the Ilorin-Ogbomoso Expressway in the Asa Local Government Area of Kwara State.
It was learnt that the accident, which occurred in Otte at about 7am, resulted from a head-on collision between a commercial Toyota Hummer bus and a Volvo truck loaded with cement.
Six of the passengers were rescued alive with burns injury while the deceased passengers were burnt beyond recognition.
The Federal Road Safety Corps blamed the accident on speed limit violation and route violation by the drivers.
The Kwara State Fire Service, which took part in the rescue operation, urged drivers to be more careful on the highway.

headline: Group campaigns against media profiling of PWDs
summarized_story:
A non-governmental organisation, Theseabilities Foundation, has called on journalists and media practitioners to desist from use of words or expressions that amount to profiling while reporting about persons with disabilities.
At the webinar, advocates and participants sought better ways to navigate through language when referring to persons with disabilities.
Alexander said, “This is particularly evident in commentaries and reporting of events and stories about persons with disabilities.
“One of the things you must bear in mind when addressing PWDs is that the language must convey respect, dignity.
Instead say something like ‘wheelchair user’ or ‘person on wheels’.

headline: Colonial masters responsible for Nigeria’s faulty foundation ― Ganduje
summarized_story:
Governor Abdullahi Ganduje of Kano State has attributed the challenges of nation building in Nigeria to the faulty foundation laid by the colonial masters.
The governor said that the faulty foundation laid by the colonial masters was purely done to actualise their interests and not for any genuine development of the country.
“The challenges of nation building in Nigeria are attributable to the very faulty foundation laid by the European colonial masters.
Ganduje said that the colonial rule divided Nigeria into North and South without much concern for the peculiarities of the two regions.
“Nation-building is about building a common sense of purpose, sense of shared destiny and collective imagination of belonging.

headline: Bamise: Gov’ship aspirant, Jandor wants perpetrators brought to justice

headline: War: You’re making dangerous move – Russia warns US against transferring weapons to Ukraine

headline: FG: No More Subsidies in Power Sector, Fuel Subsidy to Go in Phases
summarized_story:
*Says power sector subsidy removal quietly doneNdubuisi Francis in AbujaThe federal government disclosed Friday that it had quietly removed all subsidies in the power sector, even as it plans to gradually stop similar subsidies on petroleum motor spirit (PMS), popularly known as fuel.
The Minister of Finance, Budget and National Planning, Mrs. Zainab Ahmed, who made the disclosure during a virtual meeting of African finance ministers and the International Monetary Fund (IMF), said: “We are cleaning up our subsidies.
We had a setback, we were to remove fuel subsidy by July this year but there was a lot of push back from the polity.
It has thrown up our deficits too much higher than we planned.
“Hopefully, the parliament will agree with us and we are able to continue with our plan for subsidy (removal) otherwise the way things are going we will not be able to predict where we will be,” she said.

Operatives of the security outfit were said to have stormed Amankwo community on Monday, shooting sporadically.
Residents told SaharaReporters that the local security operatives also set ablaze a market in the community known as Nkwo-Idemili.
“Hope Uzodimma's so-called Ebubeagu descended on the market in my community on Monday, torched and razed down the timber section of the market.
Please help us beg the government to stop these siege and senseless killings,” a resident told SaharaReporters.

headline: Saudi Arabia executes 81 convicts -- largest mass execution in its history
summarized_story:
The kingdom of Saudi Arabia, on Saturday, announced that it had executed 81 convicted criminals.
The Saturday announcement is the largest mass execution conducted by the country in its modern history — more than the 67 executions reported in all of 2021 and 27 in 2020.
Prior to Saturday, the largest mass execution in the country’s history since 1980 was in 2016 when 47 persons were killed.
AdvertisementAccording to Saudi Press Agency (SPA), the 81 individuals were convicted of terrorism and capital crimes.
Of the 81 people killed, 73 were Saudi citizens, seven were Yemeni and one was a Syrian national.

headline: Protecting your mental health and privacy

Having good mental health and no mental illness is at the top of the spectrum, while having poor mental health and a mental illness is at the bottom.

headline: Saudi Arabia Says It Has Executed 81 Convicts in Single Day
summarized_story:
Saudi Arabia on Saturday executed 81 people convicted of a variety of crimes, including killings and belonging to militant groups, in the largest mass execution conducted by the kingdom in its modern history.
The total number of those put to death surpassed that of the January 1980 mass execution of those convicted of the seizure of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, which saw 63 people beheaded.
“The kingdom will continue to take a strict and unwavering stance against terrorism and extremist ideologies that threaten the stability of the entire world,” the report added.
The kingdom’s last mass execution came in January 2016, when the kingdom executed 47 people, including a prominent opposition Shiite cleric who had rallied demonstrations in the kingdom.
In 2019, the kingdom beheaded 37 Saudi citizens, most of them minority Shiites, in a mass execution across the country for alleged terrorism-related crimes.
